title: Eight Steps to Customer Service Success
displayTitle: Eight Steps to Customer Service Success
body:
Learning Objectives:
The Bulk Barn Customer Service Model is an eight-step process to engage customers, respond to their needs, and create a better shopping experience for them.

By the end of this course, you will be able to:
  • State the importance of the customer service model in serving customers and ensuring repeat business
  • Explain the Bulk Barn customer service model
  • Describe the different types of customer personalities and their behavior
  • Leverage the Bulk Barn model as appropriate to each customer personality

title: Managing Customers
body: As a Bulk Barn employee, you will hear many comments from our customers, both good and bad...

title: Customer Personalities
body:
No two customers are alike; that’s just human nature!
But to help you understand your customers better and learn more about their behavioral traits, we have categorized customer personalities into three general types:
mobileBody: This is optional body text that will be shown when viewed on mobile.
instruction: Click each hotspot marker on the image to continue.

_items.title: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer
_items.body:
• These customers are usually in a rush. They are likely familiar with your store and know what they are looking for.
  • These customers can easily become agitated. They usually have something else going on in their world affecting them.
  • Some customers can just be cranky, so don’t take their behaviour personally!
_items.strapline: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer

_items.title: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer
_items.body:
• These are the customers we all love – they welcome our help. But they may not always ask – so be on the lookout for this.
  • Make good use of the opportunity to work with these customers—you don’t get a chance to help them all that often!
  • While interacting with these customers, use this opportunity to sharpen your skills for more difficult customers.
_items.strapline: Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

_items.title: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer
_items.body:
• Sometimes shy customers require help, but are simply afraid to receive it when you initially ask.
  • Be available for these customers when they do need your help.
_items.strapline: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer

body: Often, customers will share more than one trait from each category, so you have to be on your toes.

title: Creating a Better Shopping Experience
body:
This course will help you manage customers with ease and make their experience with Bulk Barn more enjoyable.

That’s important, because when a customer leaves the store satisfied, there is a much greater chance of them becoming a repeat customer!

More Customers > More Sales > More Hours > Better Work Environment > Better Shopping Experience
To build your people skills and boost customer satisfaction, we’ve designed a powerful resource called the Bulk Barn Model.

Are you ready to explore it? Then let’s get started!

title: Which Employee Would You Rather Approach?
displayTitle: Which Employee Would You Rather Approach?
body: Say you are a customer and have a question about a product. Which employee would you rather approach?
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.body:
Employee One: “Gee, I'm not really sure about that. You should Google it.”

Customer: “But isn't it your job to know about your products?”
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body:
Employee Two: “This is great flour for baking. Let me share some baking ideas that have really worked out well for other customers.”

Customer: Wow, she really seems to know her stuff!
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Don’t you think the customer in scenario 2 seems more satisfied? Customer satisfaction is based not just on the products they receive but also on their experience with the store employees.

title: Customer Personalities and Coaching Tips
body: Let’s see how we can apply the “Bring It” approach with the three common categories of customers.
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.title: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer
_items.body:
• If they are not in a mood to receive your assistance and service, then it’s better to let them be on their own. You’ve done your part by welcoming them to the store and having a positive attitude.
  • Some customers are simply in a bad frame of mind or are just in a rush. So, give them space and time to complete their shopping.
  • Should they need your assistance, make sure you are immediately available.
_items.strapline: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer

_items.title: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer
_items.body:
• These customers are often looking for our help, but don’t always ask.
  • With your positive approach, and contagious attitude, you will have little problem taking this customer through the next steps.
_items.strapline: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

_items.title: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer
_items.body:
• Sometimes customers require help, but are too shy to receive it when you initially ask. Be polite and set the tone.
  • If the customer turns down your initial request to assist them, you should still keep an eye out for them. As they walk the aisles and become more comfortable in the store it may become apparent that they do require help.
  • When they do accept your help be polite, professional and patient. Be prepared to ask more questions to discover their needs.
_items.strapline: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer

title: How Does It Make You Feel?
displayTitle: How Does It Make You Feel?
body:
How does it make you feel when someone takes the time to understand what you need and as a result, you turn a good recipe into a great one?

Customer: Hey, that’s an amazing dessert suggestion. My in laws will never believe I came up with it!

Employee: Well, that’s why we’re here. Good luck with your dinner!

title: What Is Meant by “Understanding Customer Needs”?
displayTitle: What Is Meant by “Understanding Customer Needs”?
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.body: Understanding customer needs is about actively engaging a customer to understand their product needs and wants.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Identify what a customer is looking for and offer them products that suit their requirements. This will make them feel appreciated and help to build strong customer relationships.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Once you understand the customer’s needs, provide additional products and solutions that they may have been previously unaware of.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Your actions will show them that you are willing to go above and beyond typical service to ensure their needs are met and that they are totally satisfied.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: To understand customer needs, you need to ask open-ended questions that encourage customers to talk more about what they are making or what products they need.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body:
Open-ended questions are those that can’t be answered by simply yes or no.

Here are a few sample questions that you can ask to get the conversation started.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body:
• What can I help you find today?
  • What is that you are making?
  • Would you prefer gluten-free products?
  • Can you tell me more about the occasion and number of guests?
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Scroll down to continue.
_items.strapline: Scroll down to continue

title: Knowledge Check
body:
Imagine a customer has just walked into your store. You want to approach the customer to assist them in finding what they need.

What questions would you ask the customer to understand their requirements better?

_items.text: What can I help you find today?
Could you tell me about what you are preparing?
Can you tell me more about the birthday theme?
How old will the kids be

_feedback.correct: That’s right! These are all great questions that you can ask your customers to get a better understanding of their needs.

_incorrect.final: Great try but you could do better. These are all great questions that you can ask your customers to get a better understanding of their needs.

_partlyCorrect.final: Great try but you could do better. These are all great questions that you can ask your customers to get a better understanding of their needs.

title: What You Need to Do to Understand Customer Needs?
displayTitle: What You Need to Do to Understand Customer Needs?
body: To understand customer needs, you need to:
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.body: Ask the customer if they need help finding what they are looking for.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Ask open-ended questions that elicit more than just a yes or a no response.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Listen attentively to the customer to understand what products they need and how they plan to use those products.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Speak intelligently while responding to the customer’s requirements.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Demonstrate an “I’m here for you” attitude toward the customer.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Tell the customer about products we have in stock that will meet their needs.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Suggest appropriate product substitutes to the customer, if we do not carry what they are looking for.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Scroll down to continue.
_items.strapline: Scroll down to continue

title: Customer Personalities and Coaching Tips
body: Let’s see how we can better understand customer needs across different categories of customers.
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.title: The “in a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer
_items.body:
• These customers are often in a hurry and may appear to be sullen or irritated. However, often they do need our help and will ask for it. Their approach to asking for help may be abrupt or aggressive. Yet, it is our job to remain welcoming and continue to treat them like guests.
  • If this sort of customer does engage you for assistance, take on the “pace” in which they are going at. At the same time, it is important to maintain your composure, politeness and professionalism.
_items.strapline: The “in a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer

_items.title: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer
_items.body:
• Although these customers are easy to work with and are cooperative, it is still very important to ask all the right questions.
  • With these customers, it can be easy to get carried away and be overtly talkative. Maintain your
    professionalism and continue to ask questions to lead you in the right direction.
_items.strapline: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

_items.title: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer
_items.body:
• Just like the “in a hurry”, “grumpy”, and “agitated” customer, this customer will often give you short, one word responses because they are shy and timid.
  • Don’t be overly talkative. You don’t want to be intimidating or “pushy”. This customer is more sensitive to this approach and may be scared off.
  • Be patient with this customer. Mirror the customer’s tone and speech rhythm as you continue to ask questions.
_items.strapline: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer

displayTitle: Picture Yourself in the Customer’s Shoes

Employee 1:

title: Customer Personalities and Coaching Tips
body: Let’s see how you can lead our three types of customers.
mobileBody: This is optional body text that will be shown when viewed on mobile.
instruction: Click each hotspot marker on the image to continue.

_items.title: The “in a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer
_items.body:
• If this sort of customer does engage you for assistance, take on the customer’s pace.
  • However, it is important to maintain your composure, politeness and professionalism.
  • Continue to ask them questions to understand their requirement.
  • If they give you short answers, they probably aren’t interested in your help. Simply ask them if there is anything else you can do for them and give them space.
_items.strapline: The “in a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer

_items.title: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer
_items.body:
• Maintain your energy level and take this customer to the product(s) they are looking for.
  • Continue to ask the right questions as you lead this customer – they may be looking for other products and not even know it!
  • Maintain your professionalism and continue to communicate with the customer so that you can lead them in the right direction.
_items.strapline: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

_items.title: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer
_items.body:
• As you are leading this customer, be friendly and professional with them, Chances are they may just need some time to warm up to you.
  • Take on their tone, be patient with this customer, and don’t get overly boisterous or talkative.
_items.strapline: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer

body: You’ve learned how to Lead the Customer, click the arrow below to go back to the course menu.

title: What Is Meant By “Knowing the Products, Processes and Promotions”?
displayTitle: What Is Meant By “Knowing the Products, Processes and Promotions”?
body:
Knowing Products, Processes and Promotions means learning more about products, store operating processes and all current promotional activities.

Build your knowledge about your store’s products, process and promotions to help out a customer and create a positive shopping experience.

Never hesitate to ask for help or guidance from management. After all, at Bulk Barn, we’re a team!

instruction: Click the Play button below to watch the video.

title: Knowledge Check
body:
Often a customer will ask for details about products. When they do, it’s important to know the answer.

In this scenario, a customer has just asked an employee about what differentiates dark, regular and white chocolate.

Read each of the responses and select the one that you feel best demonstrates product knowledge.
instruction: Choose the correct response below and click “Submit” to continue.

_items.text:
Employee 2:
Dark chocolate tastes bitter and the other two taste sweet. My personal preference is milk chocolate.

Employee 3:
None are good for you if you eat too much of it.

Employee 4:
It comes down to how they are produced. Dark chocolate is made by combining cocoa solids, cocoa butter and sugar with little or no milk, giving it a more bitter taste.
Mild chocolate contains more dairy fat and white chocolate doesn’t contain cocoa solids, just cocoa butter, milk and sugar.

_feedback.correct: Nice work! You have helped this customer understand how ingredients impact the taste of chocolate.

_incorrect.final: Nice try but you could do better. The fourth response demonstrates the level of product knowledge our customers expect and appreciate.

_partlyCorrect.final: Nice try but you could do better. The fourth response demonstrates the level of product knowledge our customers expect and appreciate.

_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Be aware of and accurately explain all current promotions.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Understand our procedures for ringing the customer through in a timely and seamless manner – whether processing gift cards, processing seniors” & students” discounts, coupons, or any other transaction.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body:
Know how to process all register transactions including product promotions in a timely manner and with accuracy.
Know store operating and product processes and procedures, and be able to execute them with competence.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Never hesitate to ask your manager for information or an explanation. They are there to help!
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Scroll down to continue.
_items.strapline: Scroll down to continue

title: Customer Personalities and Coaching Tips
body: Let’s see how you can manage customer requests and offer them information on products, processes and promotions.
mobileBody: Let’s see how you can manage customer requests and offer them information on products, processes and promotions.
instruction: Click each hotspot marker on the image to continue.

_items.title: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer
_items.body:
• Occasionally, even knowing the product, processes and promotions can’t please this sort of customer, so don’t take it personally.
  • Simply maintain the course of the process and maintain your professionalism and positive demeanour.

_items.title: The “Cooperative”, “Happy” , “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

• This sort of customer may not even be looking for product information or information on specific promotions.
  • Make an effort to communicate. By informing them, you will build even more confidence in them and provide them with an even better shopping experience.
_items.strapline: The “Cooperative”, “Happy” , “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

• Offer this customer the right information and any specific promotion that pertains their requirement.

_items.strapline: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer

body: No matter what customer you are working with, everyone loves to hear about promotions - so be sure to share your knowledge with them.

title: Know Our Products
instruction: Click the Play button below to watch the video.

title: What Is Meant By “Believing in the Products and Processes”?
displayTitle: What Is Meant By “Believing in the Products and Processes”?
body:
Believing in the Products and Processes refers to an attitude where the employee exudes confidence and pride when speaking about our product and brand.

Our processes have been designed and built on 30 years of success. They are tried and proven – everything from cleaning to restocking, everything we do is for the customer!

The better you know the product and processes the more confident you are and the better you can assist a customer.

title: Did You Know?
body:
We follow several processes to make sure our customer receive the best quality products all the time.
Did you know?
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.body: We continuously rotate our liners and our product to ensure the freshest product for our customer.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: We sanitize every scoop in the store on a daily basis and gluten free scoops are sanitized separately from the rest.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: To guard against cross contamination, gluten free barrels and tubs are cleaned and vacuumed separately from the rest.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Pet food fixtures are vacuumed and cleaned with dedicated tools that are never used in other areas of the store.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: It’s ok if you are not familiar with these or other processes followed at Bulk Barn. In future courses, we will learn more about it.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Scroll down to continue.
_items.strapline: Scroll down to continue

title: Knowledge Check
body: At Bulk Barn, we follow the liner and rotation process. Do you know how it benefits our customers?
instruction: Select the correct option and click submit.

_items.text: We continuously rotate our liners to ensure staff have something to do.
We continuously rotate our liners and our product to ensure the freshest product for our customer.
We continuously rotate our liners so that they look nice all the time.
We continuously rotate our liners because corporate office instructs us too.

_feedback.correct: You got it! We rotate liners and product to ensure our customers receive the freshest product possible. Communicate about this product process to build confidence in our customers.

title: Customer Personalities and Coaching Tips
body: By believing in our products and being confident, you can surely win over different customers – whether they are agitated, cooperative, and shy. Let’s see how you can manage different customer personalities.
mobileBody: Let’s see how you can manage customer requests and offer them information on products, processes and promotions.
instruction: Click each hotspot marker on the image to continue.

_items.title: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer
_items.body:
• Even though these customers can be in a hurry, often they do want to ask a question or two about the product.
  • Be sure that you are available for them and only answer the questions they are asking. You will have to gauge their response as to whether or not they want more information.
  • By this step in the process, the customer is probably so pleased with you that they are no longer a “in a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and “Agitated” Customer.
_items.strapline: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer

_items.title: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer
_items.body:
• This customer has been through all of these steps with you – they have a rapport with you.
  • Demonstrating confidence in our products and processes will further build both their confidence and the quality of their experience with you and the store!
_items.strapline: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

_items.title: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer
_items.body:
• This customer may by frightful, timid and/or Shy – because they have never been in a bulk barn store, or maybe even had a poor experience in their last visit.
  • Be confident and believe in the product and our processes. This confidence could very well “rub off” on this customer, turning their slightly frightening experience into a more positive one with you and the store.
_items.strapline: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer

title: What Is Meant By “Acknowledging Customer Needs”?
displayTitle: What Is Meant By “Acknowledging Customer Needs”?
body:
Acknowledging Customer Needs and Adding-On is about listening to the customer and offering product options that will meet and/or compliment the customer’s needs/wants.

Show the customer that you have not only listened to their needs, but are offering complimentary products to help them with their requirements. This will build trust and confidence in the customer’s mind.

Let the customer know about our HUGE arrangement of products and show them additional products that will complement their shopping needs. Feel free to make new suggestions.

For example: As you are walking your customer to a requested type of baking mix, don’t be afraid to point out any other items in the aisle and talk about how other customers use that product.

title: A Few Sample Questions
body: Acknowledging customer needs is a step ahead of understanding customer needs. Here are a few sample questions that you can ask your customers to acknowledge their needs:
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.body: Are there any other supplements that you take along with Vitamin C? If you’re interested, we have several specials on this week.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Now that you have the dried apples for your daughter’s lunch, I’d like to suggest some other dried fruit favourites that are big with the kids.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: I’m glad that your Great Dane is stocked up with Tarter Buster Dog Bones. What other treats does he like? Dog owners always rave about the pig ears.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Scroll down to continue.
_items.strapline: Scroll down to continue

title: Knowledge Check

_feedback.correct:

The following questions are great questions to acknowledge customer needs since they focus on customer requirements and help confirm if they are satisfied with their purchases.

  • Will one large bag of flour be enough to last the whole summer at the cottage?

However, it is best to avoid the following question since it does not focus on customer requirements.
  • Would you like to know what trail mix I ate before the half marathon last month?

title: Customer Personalities and Coaching Tips
instruction: Click each hotspot marker on the image to continue.

_items.title: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer
_items.body:
• This customer may be in a hurry to leave the store, or may not be in a happy frame of mind but it is important that they know that you have understood what they are looking for and have done your best to “acknowledge their needs”.
  • Again this will prove to them that you were there for them and that you were trying to make their experience as positive as possible.
  • This will open an opportunity up for you to “Add on” – this customer may have just been looking for a snack or trail mix, however you’ve diffused them, earned their trust and now you can show them that they can build their own mix by purchasing their own ingredients.
_items.strapline: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer

_items.title: The “Cooperative”, “Happy” , “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer
_items.body:
• With any customer, or situation in life, it is important to show that you are listening – showing that you were paying attention to the customer’s needs and acknowledging them goes a long way.
  • This customer has been right with you the whole way through – prove to them that you can assist them even further by showing them more products that will help with their needs.
  • If this customer came in simply looking for candy molds and you have identified they are throwing a party, you need to show them the Piñatas, the wrapped candy and cello loot bags, cake pans and sprinkles – the sky is the limit.
  • Prove to this customer that we are a “one – stop shop”.
  • We not only need customers to feel welcome, but also to want to do all of their shopping with us.
_items.strapline: Cooperative”, “Happy” , “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

_items.title: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer
_items.body:
• This customer may be shy and not so willing to open up to you about their needs; however it is important that they know that you have understood what they are looking for and have done your best to “acknowledge their needs”.
This will prove to them that you were there for them and that you were trying to make their experience as positive as possible.
_items.strapline: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer

title: What Is Meant by Relationship Management?
displayTitle: What Is Meant by Relationship Management?
body:
Relationship Management is about working towards creating and maintaining an excellent customer experience in order to build a relationship with each and every customer.

Your last impression is just as important as your first. You have worked hard every step of the way – so make sure you finish off the last few steps on a high note.

You need to show them that we are here to help them, to provide a great shopping experience, and to make sure they go home happy!

title: What You Need to Do Build and Manage a Customer Relationship
displayTitle: What You Need to Do Build and Manage a Customer Relationship
body: To build a great relationship with the customer, you need to:
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.body: Greet every customer in a friendly and engaging manner.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Be available to the customer and attend to service their needs/wants.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Maintain a friendly demeanor with the customer throughout their entire visit.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Ask your manager about situations and scenarios and ensure your manager sets a standard for what is acceptable.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Be sure to ask customers if they have found everything they came in for – ensuring they are completely satisfied with their visit.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Understand that while the customer may not always be right, you still need to manage their expectations while maintaining a friendly approach.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Scroll down to continue.
_items.strapline: Scroll down to continue

title: Customer Personalities and Coaching Tips
instruction: Click each hotspot marker on the image to continue.

_items.title: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer
_items.body:
• This sort of customer can be the hardest or the easiest customer to build that relationship with.
  • Easiest in the sense that if they have entered the store in a “gnarly” disposition, and you’ve helped them the whole way through with confidence and your positive attitude, then the likelihood is that you have simmered them down and they are willing to finish their experience off on a higher note – leaving them with a better experience then when they entered the store.
  • Hardest in the sense that some people are just rude and/or in a rush and/or simply agitated with life.
  • Don’t take this personally: You’ve done your best to ensure they have had a great experience – so be proud of yourself.
_items.strapline: The “In a Hurry”, “Grumpy”, and/or “Agitated” Customer

_items.title: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer
_items.body:
• Although these customers are easy to work with and are cooperative, it is still very important to end this visit on a great note.
  • Follow all the steps of the Bulk Barn model to serve the customer better.
  • Maintain your professionalism and continue to ask the questions to lead you in the right direction.
_items.strapline: The “Cooperative”, “Happy”, “Looking for Help” and/or “Willing” Customer

_items.title: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer
_items.body:
• You have done all the steps correctly with this customer – great job – it will be surprising how quickly this customer has warmed up to you.
  • Ensure that you stick to the plan and provide them with a great last impression.
  • This “Frightful”, “Timid”, “Shy” Customer won’t be so frightful, timid or shy the next time they come in.
_items.strapline: The “Frightful”, “Timid” and/or “Shy” Customer

title: Keep Customers Visiting Again and Again
displayTitle: Keep Customers Visiting Again and Again
body:
Using the Bulk Barn model you’ve seen how we can provide our customers a great experience right from
understanding their needs to closing the visit successfully. What’s more – you need to ensure that they keep visiting again and again.

A customer’s experience begins from the minute they enter the store. A professional appearance and welcoming demeanour, the way an employee approaches the customer, understands requirements, leads them to find what they want, and helps them make a choice – determines how the customer’s experience will be.

title: What Is Meant By “Next Visit”?
instruction: Select the red forward arrow below to learn more.

_items.body: N stands for Next visit, the final step “N” in the Bulk Barn model is a goal for all employees. Employees need to provide an excellent shopping experience consistently to each customer and encourage them to return.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: It’s important to ensure that every customer receives the same outstanding treatment time and time again, from visit to visit to ensure they keep coming back.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: By creating a positive shopping experience, the customer will feel welcomed, appreciated and satisfied which will make them want to come back!
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: By following this model, you will have given it your all to ensure the customer had an outstanding trip to our store.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Scroll down to continue.
_items.strapline: Scroll down to continue

title: How to Ensure a Customer Visits the Next Time and Again?
displayTitle: How to Ensure a Customer Visits the Next Time and Again?

_items.body: Ensure an excellent and consistent shopping experience for all our customers.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Thank every customer for coming and invite them to return; even if some of the customers have not made a purchase.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

_items.body: Make the customer feel welcomed, appreciated and satisfied.
_items.strapline: Click the plus sign for more info

title: Summary
body:
This model is your guide to ensuring that customers receive an outstanding visit time and time again – from store to store.

Our customers are our number 1 priority. We need to treat them like guests, value their visit and appreciate their time.

By creating a positive shopping experience, we will ensure that customers identify our store as a fun and friendly place for all of their bulk needs and keep coming back.

title: Conclusion
body:
This course has been designed to help you achieve the highest possible standards in customer satisfaction.

But keep in mind that every course and module in the eLearning program targets that exact same objective.

Whether it is cleaning our stores

Offering a fast and efficient point of sale experience

Merchandising

Or any of the other countless processes that we do day in and day out, we are all working toward one goal:

Delivering unparalleled customer satisfaction by offering an unequaled shopping experience!
